div.p: Hello. I'm Dr. David Carr, professor of medicine in
neurology, and the Alan A and Edith L. Wolff,
professor of Geriatric Medicine at Washington
University School of Medicine in St. Louis,
Missouri. Welcome to our program titled, mild
cognitive impairment and driving safety: early
action with patients.
I'm delighted joining me today is Dr. Linda Hill is
professor in the Department of Family Medicine
and Public Health and the Department of Surgery
at the UC San Diego School of Medicine, in San
Diego, California. Also director of the UCSD SDSU
preventative medicine residency, and training,
research and education for driving safety.
Also welcome Dr. Tammy Arms, who is an
associate professor at the UNCW College of
Health and Human Services School of Nursing,
and the Nurse Faculty Leadership Academy
scholar in Wilmington, North Carolina. Welcome
to both of you. I know you both do research,
teaching and also see patients, so we're delighted
to have you on our panel today.
Just to background, some of the information that
we're going to be touching on is this area of
cognitive impairment, which we see very often in
older adults in our practice. We as clinicians need
to be aware of the different types of factors,
medications, medical conditions that can affect
driving, and makes sure we consider driving as an
important instrumental activity of daily living in
our practice. I think it's also important, not just
the safety issues, because we know that there is
some risk in driving with older adults, especially
those that have medical impairments. But we also
know older adults are risk for driving cessation.
The average older adult male may be without
driving a car for six years, a female for 10 years.
That's a long time. And what are those risk
factors? Pretty much the same as they are for
motor vehicle crashes. We know that there's age
associated illnesses, visual impairment, cognitive
decline, diminished motor strength that can occur
as we age.
Tammy, would you like to talk to us a little bit
about some of the crash statistics and some of
our concerns about older adult drivers?
Yes, thank you David. We do know that older
adults have an increased crash risk and fatality
rate per miles driven. And this is the highest in
this aging demographic compared to any other
demographics. These graphs right here actually
show us the significant change and the increased
driver fatalities.
We also know that these numbers are expected to
only increase. Dr. Hill, could you tell us a little
bit about the prevalence of cognitive impairment?
Why this is such an important issue for clinicians?
Certainly. Dementia prevalence rises with age.
Only 2.4% of individuals 65 to 74 years of age
have cognitive impairment, whereas this
percentage ranges between 34 and 50% in those
over age 85. However, primary care physicians
are missing as many as 76% of dementia cases,
and 65% of dementia diagnoses are not
documented in outpatient medical records. Part
of this trend is explained by the quarter of older
adults without overt signs of cognitive
impairment, but who failed testing when done.
The other issue is the lack of systematic screening.
We'd like to present a case that we've had in
clinic, of an 83-year-old female whose major
complaint is a short-term memory loss. She's
accompanied by her daughter in clinic, and the
daughter does raise concerns about driving. No
specifics but just in general, given mother's
slowed reaction time. Also as noted, some
repetition, some short-term memory loss, and
some of the medications and medical conditions.
A review of the record does show a past medical
history of hypertension, diabetes, and general
anxiety disorder. Her current medications are
atenolol, metformin, alprazolam, and sertraline.
So we'd like to use this case as an example as we
go through our curriculum, and address what is
MCI, and how can it potentially impact driving.
So when it comes to making the diagnosis of MCI,
there are several areas that the clinician needs to
be aware of. First of all is a concern regarding a
change in cognition. This could either be from the
collateral source, the informant, or the patient.
And clinicians need to be aware that the brain can
go down in a variety of different ways. It doesn't
just have to be short-term memory. We can be
talking language, visual spatial skill, attention,
what we call executive function, which again can
be changes in personality or behavior,
sequencing, organizing, etc. There also needs to
be documented impairment in one or more
cognitive domains.
Historically in research situations, this was done
by psychometric tests in neuro psychologists, but
clinicians can certainly assess different cognitive
domains, and we have tools like the MoCA, mini
mental status examination, and brief mental
status screens that we can apply in the clinical
setting, that will help us determine if the history
goes along with the cognitive testing.
The third aspect of a diagnosis of mild cognitive
impairment is the relative preservation or
independence in functional abilities. Now how is
the clinician to assess those abilities? One
common tool is the functional assessment
questionnaire that asks 10 questions over a
variety of different activities of daily living.
The AD-8, also known as the Alzheimer's disease
questionnaire eight, has questions, some related to
cognitive impairment, but many related to functional
decline. And finally some of the classic tools in
the geriatric literature, the Katz and Lawton tools
for basic activities of daily living and instrumental
activities of daily living that are out there.
The final aspect of a diagnosis of mild cognitive
impairment, is that the individual is not
demented. So again, we go back to this issue
where we're not seeing functional impairment,
and there's also no impairment in social or
occupational functioning. The diagnosis of MCI
that we just mentioned is compatible with the
DSM-V criteria, mild neurocognitive disorder.
But I think there are some key points that need
to be discussed for clinicians if they're going to
tackle this diagnosis in their office.
We get into semantics, but theoretically with MCI,
you shouldn't have functional impairment. So if
somebody had some cognitive decline that is
obviously infecting their driving, one could
actually classify that individual as having a
dementing illness, which makes sense. It's not
always obvious, and that's part of what our
discussion and curriculum is today. I think it's also
fair to say, as you know, especially in patients that
have short-term memory impairment, they may
not be very accurate in their histories. So we
really urge clinicians to allow a person who knows
the patient to come in and have that dialogue.
Many clinicians feel comfortable diagnosing
Alzheimer's disease in an MCI phase. However,
progression is variable, and we know that similar
to dementia, MCI is a syndrome, and there's a lot
of different causes. And clinicians need to rule out
those reversible causes for cognitive decline.
I think it's also important for many of us that
follow our patients that we've labeled with MCI,
many do stay stable over time.
Finally, I think it's also important to make two
additional points. One is that it's not all about
short-term memory. We mentioned that before.
There are other cognitive domains, language
decline, executive dysfunction, attention, visual
spatial impairment, that we need to ask about.
And I think it's also fair to say that no
pharmacological interventions have been shown
useful in this state.
So in going on with our case, as we interviewed
both the patient and the daughter, they both
endorsed short-term memory loss. The individual
could repeat questions, misplace items. This was
further corroborated on a MoCA score, which
showed impaired recall. Currently there was no
obvious impairment in social, occupational or IDL
function. So based on both the history and exam,
felt like this was a diagnosis of mild cognitive
impairment. So in this situation, we do believe
that working individuals up for reversible causes
of dementia is indicated.
One of our mnemonics that we typically use in
geriatrics is DEMENTIA where D is for drugs.
So we need to consider medications that can mimic
Alzheimer's disease or related disorders.
Emotional disorders such as anxiety or depression
which we know can affect older adults’ cognition.
Metabolic disorders such as obstructive sleep
apnea that can cause hypoxia. Sensory
deprivation, nutritional deficiencies such as B12.
Brain injuries, infections and vascular issues such
as stroke or seizure disorders, can be in the
differential diagnosis and need to be considered.
Now in our patient, we did some screens that
helped supplement and look for some of these
causes. One that we recommend to clinicians is
adopting the Epworth sleepiness scale, which
basically is a tried and true scale for
hypersomnolence. Score of 10 or greater is an
abnormal score. Doesn't necessarily mean
somebody has a primary sleep disorder, may be
either sedated from their benzos or their
anticholinergic drugs. But if you see a level and
this individual has a score of 12, that's a concern.
The patient health questionnaire, which basically
follows the outline for DSM five criteria for major
depression disorder, is a nice screen that
clinicians can adopt. And in this individual, she
had a score of 12 which showed some mild
depressive symptomatology. Thankfully there was
no history of hypoglycemia, but the medication
review did identify a concerning drug, alprazolam.
Now before we can go on with a further
evaluation in the clinical setting, what do we
know about MCI in the driving literature? Well,
the studies are few, but they tend to line up with
two general findings. One is that individuals with
mild cognitive impairment on average appear to
have more errors when performing driving
simulation tasks, or on the road tests. However,
on the positive side, studies have shown the
potential for training and education can
potentially improve driving safety behaviors.
Improvement in simulation performance, and
improvement in on the road testing was noted in
a couple of interventions. Again, small studies,
nothing's been proven, but I think it shows some
optimism that this may be a group that could
benefit by education.
Tammy, would you like to talk to a little bit about
additional information we could obtain in the
clinic that might put older adults at risk for
driving impairment?
Absolutely. As a clinician, sometimes we have to
be a detective, if you will, and be alert to some
red flags on our medical exam and history taking.
So when we're taking the history of the patient,
from the patient as well as any family members
that may be included, we really need to be alert
to any medical conditions, any sensory conditions
or cognitive motor changes, as well as the
medications that you've identified. As well as
really looking at that functional decline that our
older patients sometimes do have.
And so we're looking for any type of decreased
short-term memory, which you discussed, and
obtained that information through the MoCA
screening. Decreased or impaired way finding.
You see this especially with road construction.
Somebody having more difficulty finding their
way around road constructions and detours.
Somebody who's being reportedly easily
distracted. And not really able to learn new
information as quickly as they used to.
Near misses and unexplained crashes. An older
adult's car may have scratches or unexplained
dents that a family member may recognize. Poor
judgment making left turns, sensory depth
perceptions can actually cause some of this
problem. Confusing the gas and brake pedal, of
course, is a big thing that needs to be looked at.
Getting lost while driving.
Difficultly merging and changing lanes is also
something that needs to be really considered
because you have the physical mobility that you
need to be able to turn your neck to be able to
see, as well as, again, that decision making
equipped judgment, and literature's also showing
us that older adults who have falls are also at an
increased risk of motor vehicle crashes.
Sometimes you might see a patient with an older
adult child who actually makes comments such as,
"I'm afraid to ride with my mom, my dad," or,
"I don't feel comfortable letting my children actually
in the car riding with my mom or my dad." These
are really big comments and concerns and you
really, as a provider, cannot discount these
comments because it's telling you that there is a
big concern here for their safety as well as the
safety of other drivers on the road.
So, the Clinician's Guide, the fourth edition, has
recently come out. This describes the clinical
team that we create around our older adult
drivers, as well as their families and when the
appropriate time is for driving retirement. And
then it also helps us identify who is at risk for
unsafe driving. Again, we don't want people
having to give up driver's license that aren't ready
to do so because, again, if that is the case, they're
losing some of their independence too early and
we don't want that.
Some of the screening tools that you've
identified, the functional assessments.
Oftentimes, an older patient may become quite
defensive if they hear the term "driving
cessation," "driving retirement."
Looking at clinical interventions that can be done
to help someone maintain driving independence
as long possible.
Transitioning into driving retirement, again, has to
be an ongoing conversation. There are some legal
and ethical issues that we have to consider when
it comes to this. State reporting laws vary in every
state. And in the Clinician's Guide, there are
reference tables that discuss different medical
conditions and functional deficits, as well as
medications that providers really need to be
aware of that can affect driving abilities.
So, how about some of the team members and
who can we turn to help us with some
of these challenges?
That's a great question because a lot of us don't
feel comfortable making this decision alone, and
we really shouldn't because we do have a team of
professionals that we can communicate with and
collaborate with. Occupational therapists are one
professional colleague that we can turn to, as
many of them are professionals in identifying
when a person really should stop driving.
We do have driving rehabilitation specialists as
well as neuropsychologist who can perform some
of the psychometric testing that you referenced
into the case. Social workers can also help us
identify alternative forms of transportation for
people. Medical assistants can help us in
identifying some of those functional declines.
Traffic safety professionals actually is a very global
term to include our law enforcements as well as
DMV professionals. The Clinician's Guide office-
based screening tests could be inconclusive, and
further testing and assessments may be needed.
For example, neurology or neuropsychological
testing or social work may need to be brought in.
So Linda, clinicians have a lot of options for
different tests that they can do in the office
setting and we'd like to hear a little bit more
about your perspectives on when and how often
these tests should be done and what are the
choices that we have.
I suggest starting screening at 70. And then, I do it
about every two to three years, although I do it
earlier and more frequently if I see signs of MCI or
a decline in baseline driving skills, either reported
by my patient or the caregivers.
I do take a thorough medical history to identify
any conditions characterized by lapses of
consciousness, which may require reporting to
the DMV. So, this includes dementia, seizures,
loss of consciousness, brain tumors, and
abnormal metabolic states associated with a loss
of consciousness. I do obtain a thorough
medication history to rule out any medications
that may be interfering with driving.
So, what are some of these office screening tools?
The Clinician's Guide recommends formally
screening for vision, frailty, and cognitive decline,
starting with vision and strength testing. The
details are outlined in the guide. The tests were
selected based on an extensive review of the
literature, as well as the counsel of an expert
panel. Some of these assessments can be
conducted by the medical assistant or nurse in
your office, allowing me as the clinician to
interpret and manage the results.
While there are many cognitive assessments
available, these tests were selected because they
are simple and quick, done with pencil and paper,
and can be administered by a clinician. The Maze
test is first and is a required element of screening.
Failure is if it takes longer than 60 seconds, with
or without errors.
The cognitive tests are the MoCA or the trail
making B and clock drawing. Trail making and
clock drawing are components of the MoCA. The
MoCA's a 10-minute test that's measured by
performance on 11 components. It's available in
multiple languages and is scored on a scale of 1 to
30, with additional points being added if the
patient has less than 12 years of formal education.
The next cognitive assessment is the trail making
test. It evaluates cognitive skills, as the goal is to
have the patient make logical connections from
one item to another, according to the rules.
Corrective lenses should be worn as vision
impairment could impact the test results.
Administering trail making A prior to trail making
B improves sensitivity and specificity and is
consistent with studies that have used these tools
to predict driving performance.
Trail making B is shown here. Instruct the patient
to alternate numbers and letters. Start the timer
at the beginning of the test. If the patient makes
a mistake, have them go back to the last correct
number or letter and continue, but don't stop the
clock. Stop the timer when finished or at five
minutes. Refusal or quitting is scored as a failure.
The interpretation of trail making's very simple;
a time of greater than 180 seconds is a failure.
However, screening tests for dementia can result
in false positives due to depression, visual
impairment, or metabolic disorders, such as
hypoglycemia. Medications can also interfere
with cognitive function on a temporary basis.
While normal controls complete trail making in
less than 81 seconds, individuals with MCI
average 130 seconds to completion.
If you do not do the MoCA, the final test is the
clock drawing test. Tell the patient to draw a clock
on a piece of paper as a child would. Ask them to
draw the face of the clock, put in all the numbers,
and set the time to 10 minutes after 11:00. The
interpretation is based on the presence of the
numbers 1 through 12 in order inside the circle,
evenly spaced from each other and the edge, only
two clock hands, and one hand pointing to two
with no intrusive marks. This can be scored on a
seven-point scale or pass/fail. This test has the
advantage of only requiring numeracy and not
literacy, and is culturally appropriate across
groups. Failure of the test or refusal is highly
predictive of dementia. MCI cannot be diagnosed
with this pass/fail format, but scoring each
element individually may have some utility in
distinguishing MCI from dementia.
Linda, thank you for all that information on
screening. In going back to our case in talking with
both the patient and the daughter, our patient
had no history of prior driving performance
issues. The alprazolam, since it has been
associated with increased crash risk in older
adults, was slowly tapered off. Sertraline was
increased for depression and for anxiety
symptoms. Thankfully, visual acuity corrected and
was 20/40, which is generally legal in most states.
Test results reviewed with the patient’s daughter
and the patient was counseled that she continued
to drive, but given her diagnosis of MCI and also
her trajectory, which was concerning, we wanted
her back to be reassessed in the office in six months.
So, Dr. Hill, talk to us a little bit about some of the
next steps when it comes to following our
patients that have been diagnosed with MCI.
The screening test for medically-related driving
impairments include four domains: vision, frailty,
lapses of consciousness, and cognition. For those
failing vision or frailty testing without a reversible
cause, driving cessation should be discussed and
reporting to the DMV considered. Lapses of
consciousness may have treatable causes, such as
hypoglycemia, and are also reportable in some
states. In the work-up of cognitive decline, only
those with MCI and mild dementia should be
evaluated further for driving abilities, since
moderate and severe dementia diagnoses are not
compatible with safe driving and dementia's
reportable in some states.
When MCI is diagnosed, look for reversible
causes, as we've discussed, and assess for
amnestic components. Those with single-domain
MCI who are non-amnestic can continue driving
but need to be followed yearly. If an amnestic
component is present, obtain an on-the-road
assessment or simulator testing. Those failing
should be advised to retire from driving. Those
passing with amnestic MCI should be followed
up in six months.
So, Tammy, tell us a little bit about these health
professionals, that may be able to help us in
evaluating our patients.
Actually I'd like to take a step back for a second
if I might, and just say that DRSs are highly trained
to evaluate and teach, but there are so few of them.
They are not always available, and there may be
other instrumental activities of daily
living issues going on.
So, a referral to an occupational therapist for a
comprehensive evaluation of IADLs can offer a lot
of information to determine if the person has no
indication of issues or is so impaired that they
cannot follow a two-step direction, or is not ready
for a driving evaluation.
This comprehensive evaluation by the
occupational therapist can also tell us if a person
would benefit from a comprehensive driving
evaluation. Seeing the occupational therapist is
equivalent to using appropriate cutoff scores on
screening tools, and OTs are best able to decide
whether the referral to a specialist is needed.
It is sort of like using triage just as
in any medical setting.
So, Linda, what are some other conditions that
might impact driving that clinicians
should be aware of?
It's important to address individuals with MCI and
assess them holistically for other driving impairing
medical conditions, such as those listed here, and
treat as appropriate. For example, obstructive
sleep apnea warrants sleep studies and CPAP if
appropriate. Hypoglycemia from diabetes can be
managed with improved control.
Unfortunately, as we age, we also tend to
accumulate prescribed and OTC daily
medications. There are numerous medications
that can reduce the ability to drive safely when
taken alone, and often the effects are multiplied
as two or more drugs interact. There are many
mechanisms by which medication acts to impair
the driving task, although delayed reaction time
and drowsy driving may be more common ones,
other potential drug side effects include dizziness,
confusion, and blurred vision.
Medications can potentially enhance driving
ability, such as non-sedating pain medications or
Parkinson medications, for example, where the
symptoms are improved but they don't have side effects.
Ultimately, de-prescribing, where possible, is the
best practice. Avoiding high-risk drug classes,
using the lowest possible doses, will also reduce
the effects of prescription medication on driving.
An estimated 35% of dementia is preventable
with the adoption of the protective behaviors
listed here. We should educate our patients on
the risks of tobacco, alcohol, cannabis and
obesity. Encouraging exercise and a healthy diet is
a great idea, and control of hearing loss and
hypertension is also beneficial in preventing
cognitive decline.
So this is exciting since we have the potential to
actually prolong safe driving life expectancy with
healthy lifestyle behaviors. Again, nothing proven,
but there's a lot of potential there and certainly
we recommend that in the primary care setting.
Tammy, can you talk to us a little bit about some
of the courses and other things that may be
available out there to help preserve driving skills?
Yeah, sometimes patients may ask us what they
can do to preserve driving capabilities. And these
courses I'm going to mention are available,
although they have not been proven to improve
driving safety.
There is recent evidence, albeit small, that should
not discourage participation and certainly
encourage further study. And these you would be
able to find on the AARP websites, the AAA online
defensive driving courses, traffic school-based
driving courses, and DMV driving courses.
So to follow up on our case, one year later the
patient came back and unfortunately, as was the
initial concern, the patient had progressed. The
daughter noted worsening cognitive decline in
memory and in judgment. There was more
functional decline in the way of cooking, cleaning,
and keeping the house tidy. And now the patient
met official criteria for dementia and Alzheimer's
disease. In addition, when reviewing some of the
driving behaviors, there was a minor crash that
occurred when backing into a car in a parking lot,
and indeed the cognitive scores had declined.
Trail Making Test B was now over 200 seconds,
and clock drawing was much more impaired with
a score of two, or a fail.
So in this situation, we recommended driving
retirement. We did not believe that on-road
assessment was indicated based on the
information that we had at hand. The patient was
resistant to retiring from driving, so we did make
a referral to case manager or social services to
assist with this.
So Tammy, what can you suggest to clinicians
regarding how can we help our older adults stay
socially connected?
One thing that we need to do is we need to
discuss driving retirement plans long before they
are needed. So there are five As that we need to
look at when we're talking to our patients and our
families. These are also in the Clinician’s Guide.
Availability of alternate transportation when the
person needs it the most.
Accessibility of alternate transportations.
Acceptability of alternate forms of transportation
needs to be considered, such as the cleanliness,
or the standards, or whether or not the
neighborhood is safe for the person to get to
these alternate forms of transportation.
Affordability of forms of transportation must be
considered as many older adults are living
on a fixed income.
Adaptability is the fifth A in the Clinician’s Guide.
And this can be talking about their current vehicle
and whether or not their vehicle can be adapted
to prolong their safe driving, and again, prolong
driving life expectancy if appropriate for the person.
Conversations with the patients and family, again,
have to be ongoing, we need to have a very
holistic approach where we include all of the
clinical team members that we've recently
discussed in this conversation. We want to use
objective testing that we have talked about to
explain to the person and their family about the
safety concerns. When we use the objective
measures, it eliminates or decreases the amount
of emotional response that people have. Some
patients that I've had have actually responded
better to having a written prescription indicating
that they really should stop driving. The
conversation really should begin at the time of
diagnosis, as soon as we understand that the
diagnosis will be progressive.
Appropriate language such as driving retirement
should be used, rather than one is unable or unfit
to drive any longer.
Tammy, I think that's a great point, because when
you think about it, so many times people will
show up on our doorstep and it's like, "Oh my
God, they need to be off the road," and it's such a
difficult pill to swallow for patients and families.
Absolutely. You don't want the patient to feel like
they're being ganged up on by the team, but you
want to be working with the patient. Motivational
interviewing skills help with this. And unless there
are no other choices for safety concerns, do not
abruptly take the keys away from somebody.
So we also can get into this issue of reporting. Are
there situations where we will consider reporting
and how do we do that, Linda?
It's a really complex issue. The laws vary from
state to state. The Clinician’s Guide outlines
details about this process. MCI is generally not
reportable and only dementia.
So where else can one find assistance? In general,
if a clinician wants more information about MCI
and diagnosis, the Alzheimer's Association has an
amazing website, the AD Education Referral
center also [is] good. If clinicians want more
information on screening and assessment, they
can go to the Clinician's Guide and there are other
countries that keep up-to-date manuals on
medical conditions. A couple that come to mind
are the CMA, Canadian Medical Association. And
when it comes to assessment, as we said, we
prefer to have someone who's, if there's going to
be a performance-based road test, that's familiar
with memory problems, cognitive domains in
driving. One can do some research to look for
some of these individuals if they're in your area
through the American Occupational Therapy
Association website.
Finally, if you're having difficulty in finding those
mobility options or those driving destinations,
referral to a case manager, eldercare locator,
perhaps a referral to the Association on Aging
that's local, may have some tips on where other
transportation options are available to our clients.
So in conclusion, MCI and dementia are increasing
in prevalence with our aging population. We
know that certain levels of cognitive decline will
adversely affect driving skills and safety, and
certainly if one continues to progress like a
neurodegenerative disease, eventually
driving will have to stop.
Older drivers in your clinic should be assessed
routinely for cognitive function. If there are
concerns and it's appropriate, assess with some of
the driving red flags and certainly rule out
reversible causes are in order. The diagnosis of
MCI should prompt further assessment if those
red flags or declines or failed screens are found.
Again, we'd like to summarize. Consider
recommending adopting healthy lifestyle
behaviors, because you may not only help the
brain but prolong driving life expectancy.
Dr. Hill, Dr. Arms, thank you both so much for
being here. It was great to hear your perspectives
on assessing and counseling older drivers, and
especially those with mild cognitive impairment.
We also want to thank you for participating in this
activity. Please continue on to answer the
questions that follow and complete the evaluation.
After you answer the questions that follow and
complete the evaluation, please take a moment
to review the other activities on the collection
page titled Driver Safety: The Clinician’s
Connection, where we address driver safety issues.
